Complementary colors are two colors opposite to each other on the color wheel. These create a high contrast, so it\'s a good idea to use it, to make something stand out. For example, use one color as the background and the other for accents. Used together these colors appear brighter and more prominent.

Monochromatic colors are the same base color, with different tones and tints. They provide a subtle and minimalistic looking color combination. Monochromatic colors are easy to apply to design and project a harmonious look.

Analogous colors are three color side by side on the color wheel. This combination, though very versatile can look overwhelming, used wrong. To balance this out, it’s a good idea to choose one dominant color, and use the other two as accents

Split complementary colors use one color and match it up with two colors adjacent to its complementary color. This tactic is good for beginners because it’s difficult to mess it up. The base color should dominate, supported by the two other colors for highlights and accents.

Triadic colors are three, evenly spaced colors on the color wheel. They provide a high-contrast, but more balanced look than complementary colors. It’s a good idea, to choose one dominant color and let the other two function as supporting colors.

Tetradic colors are four colors, evenly spaced colors on the color wheel. You can either use it as a double complementary set, or choose one dominating color and let the other three support it. This tactic is the hardest to pull off, because of the difficulty in balancing the colors out.
